title: Quiz 5: Intrapersonal Health Theories (HBM, TTM, TPB)
topicName: Principles & Practice of Health Promotion I
description: Test your application of individual-level behavior change theories: HBM, Stages of Change, and TPB.

questions.question: Order the stages of the Trans-theoretical Model (Stages of Change) from first to last:
questions.explanation: No intention -> Thinking about it -> Planning -> Doing -> Sustaining -> Habit.

questions.question: Match the Health Belief Model construct with the correct intervention strategy:

richContent.content:
ConstructDefinition
SusceptibilityBelief about chance of getting condition
SeverityBelief about seriousness

pairs.right: Define populations at risk and risk levels
Explain how, where, and when to take action
Provide training, guidance, and goal setting

questions.explanation: Susceptibility needs risk info; Benefits needs positive results info; Cues needs reminders; Self-efficacy needs skill building.
questions.hint: Match the belief to what the health worker should DO.

questions.question: In the Theory of Planned Behavior (TPB), which factor refers to beliefs about whether key people approve or disapprove of a behavior?
questions.explanation: Subjective Norm is the social pressure or belief about what others think you should do.

questions.question: A person has no intention of taking action within the next six months. Which stage of change are they in?
questions.explanation: Pre-contemplation is the stage where there is no intention to change in the foreseeable future.

questions.question: According to the HBM, if a person does not feel sick (asymptomatic), they may not take medication because they lack:
questions.explanation: If they don't feel sick, they don't believe they are susceptible to the condition or its consequences.
questions.hint: They don't think they have the problem.

questions.question: In the Trans-theoretical Model, relapse is impossible once a person reaches the Maintenance stage.
questions.explanation: False. The model is cyclical, and relapse can occur at any stage, returning the person to an earlier stage.
questions.hint: Is behavior change a straight line?

questions.question: Which construct involves confidence in one's ability to take action?
questions.explanation: Self-efficacy (Bandura) is the belief in one's capability to execute the course of action required.

questions.question: In TPB, 'Perceived Behavioral Control' refers to the belief that performing the behavior is ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: It asks: Do you believe performing the behavior is up to you, or not up to you?

questions.question: Which of the following are key beliefs required for behavior change in the Health Belief Model? (Select all that apply)

options.text: They are susceptible to the condition

questions.explanation: Susceptibility, Severity, Benefits vs Barriers, Cues to Action, and Self-Efficacy are the key components. Friend approval is TPB (Subjective Norm).
questions.hint: Think about personal risk and benefit analysis.

questions.question: For a person in the 'Contemplation' stage, what is the best intervention strategy?

options.text: Motivate and encourage making specific plans
Increase awareness of need for change

questions.explanation: Contemplators intend to act soon; they need motivation to move to Preparation. Awareness is for Pre-contemplation.
questions.hint: They are thinking about it, so help them decide.
